awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Assessing Drivers of Climate Model Biases on the Pacific Continental Shelf of Antarctica
awd_abstract_narration:
Oceanographic processes in the Pacific sector of coastal Antarctica exhibit global interactions, including contribution of Antarctic ice-sheets to sea level rise, changes in the Earth's radiative balance, air/sea gas exchange through sea-ice variability, deep water formation, and Southern Ocean biological productivity. Atmosphere-ocean general circulation models (GCMs) are useful tools for understanding the complex interactions between global climate, the Antarctic coastal ocean, the cryosphere (sea ice, ice shelves, and grounded, marine-based ice sheet), and Antarctic ecosystems. 

Current-generation GCMs exhibit substantial biases in their projections of present-day hydrography and sea ice state. Previous projections of the coastal cryosphere have applied simple bias corrections. However, this approach does not remedy the underlying physical and numerical errors responsible for these biases.  This project seeks the relevance of biases to the interpretation of GCM projections by identifying their local and/or remote origins and their variation across regions and with different climate models. It will leverage the wealth of new simulations becoming available through the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project, phase 6 (CMIP6), and will focus on the rapidly-changing Pacific sector of the coastal Antarctic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project extends our scientific understanding of Antarctic Continental Shelf (ACS) hydrography (temperature and salinity) through the improvement of observational datasets and the evaluation of climate models. Our primary interest is in the relationship between ACS hydrography and melting of the Antarctic ice shelves; if melting increases, the ice shelves thin, which would increase the flow of the grounded Antarctic Ice Sheet into the ocean to raise sea level. Climate models that are unable to generate reliable maps of ACS hydrography will lead to poor estimates of future ice sheet loss. We found, however, that previous datasets of ACS hydrography also included substantial errors. A model comparison with a poor dataset might lead to an unfair assessment of the model.

We therefore began the project by investigating how to reduce errors in the gridded hydrographic dataset with which model performances are judged. We obtained all available hydrographic data from NOAA's World Ocean Database (WOD), then developed analysis methods to grid these data into a time-averaged modern-era hydrographic grid. We found that some data types (especially Expendable Bathythermographs (XBTs)) have large data errors, even after quality control at NOAA, so that substantial additional quality control is needed before including these data in gridding. We also found that most substantial errors in ACS hydrography in the existing NOAA World Ocean Atlas 2018 (WOA-18) grid product from NOAA can be removed by including data from instrumented seals; these records now dominate the full dataset of hydrographic profiles from the ACS. We then developed a technique for gridding the sparse hydrographic data to account for the strong control of bathymetry on ACS ocean currents.  We do this during gridding and interpolation by assigning larger weights to data from water depths closer to the depth at the gridding point.

We used our new grid of deep temperature on the ACS to show the relationship between the rates of basal melting of Antarctica's ice shelves and the ACS hydrographic properties. We found that ice shelves near cold deep water on the ACS produce meltwater at two levels, which then enters the coastal ocean at different depths. Melting under thick ice is associated with flows of cold, dense water from the ACS to under the ice shelves, and these flow change on multi-year time scales. The shallower melt region is associated with more seasonal variability of upper-ocean water. The different modes of time variability of the two melt regions can provide insights into how the two-way interaction between the ACS and ice shelves might change for future climates.

We also investigated a new approach to assess the performance of climate models on the ACS. This method relies on automated "clustering" of hydrographic data to define regions for comparisons between models and data. This approach allows us to separate models according to different types of errors. For example, some models represent physical processes very well but struggle because they are based on poor bathymetry, while others with better bathymetry grids do not represent the physical processes of water mass changes very well.

Our results were reported in two peer-reviewed publications, presentations at two international meetings, and through workshops and telecons.

Ongoing efforts are focused on finalizing and distributing datasets and performing a broad evaluation of the mean ACS state across all available CMIP6 (Climate Model Intercomparison Project, Phase 6) simulations. This work will help identify the set of models that best represent the modern-era hydrography on the ACS, towards assessing likely future states that will affect Antarctica's contribution to global sea level rise.  

The project supported the training of a postdoctoral fellow at Atmospheric and Environmental Research Inc., and supported the involvement of PI Padman in collaborations with glaciologists focused on Antarctic Ice Sheet mass change. In addition, the investigation of errors in the World Ocean Database around Antarctica will prove valuable in future studies of ocean/ice-sheet interactions.
